title: Letraset type/dry transfer type
content:
I have been really wanting to buy some dry transfer type to experiment with, since I lack the funds to purchase a letterpress at the current time. Does anyone know where I could buy some, or have any they'd want to sell?

Thanks!
author: becker513

comments.content: Check Ebay, I've bought some recently.
dry transfer lettering as a substitute for letterpress?

is any of the dry transfer still viable? i have about 300 sheets, and it's all SO DRY it's brittle and cracks when i mess with it.  
cost me hundreds of $, though, and i can't bring myself to throw it away, just like the Color-Aid paper i bought 25 years ago...

[Letraset.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020120502/http:/www.letraset.com/shopdisplaycategories.asp?id=139&cat=Transfer+Lettering&ssctn=default) have a very limited selection available. They still sell these in my local graphics supply shop.

_is any of the dry transfer still viable? i have about 300 sheets, and it’s all SO DRY it’s brittle and cracks when i mess with it._

I came across my stash when I was making room for a new printer -- I've used it for a couple of things since and it works fine.

_cost me hundreds of $, though, and i can’t bring myself to throw it away, just like the Color-Aid paper i bought 25 years ago…_

ROFL! I've got a small one around somewhere from a colour theory class I taught 15 years or so ago, should give it to a friend who does collages....
It was so dang expensive, I know what you mean, Chuck. :-)
